list.title: Question 3
list.content:
Consider the expansion of $(2x−1)9$.


Write down the number of terms in this expansion. [1]



Find the coefficient of the term in $x2$. [5]
list.markScheme:
The number of terms in this expansion is
$10​$


The term in $x2$ is
$$$(79​)[(2x)9−7][(−1)7]​=36[4x2][−1]=−144x2​$$$
Hence the coefficient of the term in $x2$
is  $−144​$

list.title: Question 4

Hence the coefficient of the term in $x6$

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
The coefficient of the variable $x5$ in the expansion of $(x+2a)8$, where $a∈R$, is $56$.
Find the value of $a$.
list.markScheme:
Using the binomial theorem, we have
$$$(x+2a)8​=x8+(18​)(x)7(2a)1+...+(r8​)(x)(8−r)(2a)r+...+(2a)8​(M1)​$$$
We need to identify the $rth$ term which includes $x5$, hence, $r=8−5=3$,
$$$(A1)$$$
Therefore
$$$(38​)(x5)(2a)3​=56x5​A1​$$$
Using the formula we can evaluate the binomial coefficient
$$$(38​)​=3!5!8!​=56​A1​$$$
$$$(56)(x5)(8a3)8a3a3​=56x5=1=81​a=21​​​A1A1​$$$

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
Show that $(2n−1)3+(2n+1)3=16n3+12n$ for $n∈Z$.
[3]



Hence, or otherwise, prove that the sum of the cubes of any two
consecutive odd integers is divisible by four. [3]
list.markScheme:
We have
$$$(2n−1)3​=(2n)3−3(2n)2+3(2n)−1=8n3−12n2+6n−1​$$$
and
$$$(2n+1)3​=(2n)3+3(2n)2+3(2n)+1=8n3+12n2+6n+1​$$$
Summing our expressions for $(2n−1)3$ and $(2n+1)3$, we get
$$$(2n−1)3+(2n+1)3​=8n3−12n2+6n−1​+8n3+12n2+6n+1​​$$$
Hence we get
$$$(2n−1)3+(2n+1)3=16n3+12n​​$$$


Let $2n−1$ and $2n+1$ be two consecutive odd integers for some
$n∈Z$.
The sum of the cubes of $2n−1$ and $2n+1$ is
$$$(2n−1)3+(2n+1)3​=16n3+12n[by part (a)]=4n(4n2+3)[multiple of 4]​$$$
Hence the sum of the cubes of any two consecutive odd integers is
divisible by four.

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
The third term, in descending powers of $x$, in the expansion of $(x+p)8$ is $252x6$. Find the
possible values of $p$.
list.markScheme:
Using the binomial theorem, we have
$$$252x6​=(28​)(x8−2)(p2)(1)​$$$
Hence, solving the equation $(1)$ for $p$, we get
$$$252x6252​=28(x6)(p2)=28p2​$$$
$$$p=±3​[by using G.D.C.]$$$

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
In the expansion of $(a+bx)6$, the coefficient of the $x3$ term is $−2$ times the coefficient of the $x4$ term.
Determine the value of $ba​$.
list.markScheme:
From the formula booklet we can find the formula for a general term of the expansion
$$$(a+b)n​=...+(rn​)an−rbr+...​$$$
Using the general term above, we can write an expression for the $x3$ term and the $x4$ term.
$$$​(36​)(a)3(bx)3​(46​)(a)2(bx)4​A1A1​$$$
We can now use the information given to write an equation linking the coefficients of the two expressions above.
$$$​(36​)a3b3=−2×(46​)a2b4​M1​$$$
Using the formula we can evaluate the binomial coefficients and simplify
$$$hack​M1​$$$
$$$3!3!6!​a3b33!×3×2×16×5×4×3!​a3b320a3b3​=−2×4!2!6!​a2b4=−2×4!×2×16×5×4!​a2b4=−30a2b4​A1​$$$
We need to find the value of $ba​$ therefore we can rearrange the expression above
$$$a2b4a3b3​ba​​=20−30​=2−3​​=−1.5​A1​$$$

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
Consider the expansion of
$(2x2​+xa​)6$. The constant term is
$960$.
Find the possible values of $a$.
list.markScheme:
Using the binomial theorem, we have
$$$960​=(46​)[2x2​]6−4[xa​]4(1)​$$$
Hence, solving the equation $(1)$ for $a$, we get
$$$960960​=15[4x4​][x4a4​]=415a4​​$$$
$$$a=±4​[by using G.D.C.]$$$

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
Consider the expansion of $bx(x+a)7​$, where $a>0$. The coefficient of the term in $x5$ is $2$, and the coefficient of the term in $x3$ is $1690$.
Find the value of $a$ and the value of $b$.
list.markScheme:
Because each term in the expansion of $(x+a)7$ will be divided by $bx$, we require the terms in $x6$ and $x4$. Using the Binomial Theorem, we have
$$$Term in x6Term in x4​=(17​)x6a=7x6a=(37​)x4a3=35x4a3​$$$
Dividing both these terms by $bx$ we get
$$$bx7x6a​bx35x4a3​​=b7x5a​=b35x3a3​​$$$
Given that the coefficient of $x5$ is $2$, and the coefficient of $x3$ is $1690$, we have
$$$b7a​b35a3​​=2=1690​$$$
And therefore
$$$7a35a3​=2b=1690b​[1][2]​$$$
Dividing equation [2] by equation [1] we have
$$$7a35a3​5a2a2a​=2b1690b​=845=169=±13​$$$
Given that $a>0$, $a=13​$. Substituting into equation [1],
$$$7a7(13)​=2b=2bb=45.5​​$$$

list.title: Question 11

In the expansion of $px2(5+px)8$, the coefficient of the term in

$$$3402x63402​=px2[70][54][p4x4]=43750p5​$$$

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
Consider the expansion of $(3x+xp​)8$, where
$p>0$. The coefficient of the term
in $x4$ is equal to the coefficient of the term in $x6$. Find $p$.
list.markScheme:
Using the binomial theorem, we have
$$$(3x+xp​)8​=k=0∑8​(k8​)[3x]8−k[xp​]k=k=0∑8​(k8​)[38−kpk][x8−2k]​$$$
Hence we get
$$$[coefficient of the term in x4](28​)[38−2p2]28[36p2]20412p2−17496p​=[coefficient of the term in x6]=(18​)[38−1p]=8[37p]=0​$$$
$$$p=76​​≈0.857...[by using G.D.C.]$$$

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
Let $f(x)=(x2+a)5$.
In the expansion of the derivative, $f′(x)$, the coefficient of the term
in $x5$ is $960$. Find the possible values of $a$.
list.markScheme:
Using the chain rule, we have
$$$f′(x)​=5(x2+a)4(2x)=10x(x2+a)4​$$$
Hence, using the binomial theorem, we
have
$$$960x5​=10x(24​)[(x2)4−2][a2](1)​$$$
Hence, if we solve the equation $(1)$ for $a$, we get
$$$960x5960​=10x[6][x4][a2]=60a2​$$$
$$$a=±4​[by using G.D.C.]$$$

list.title: Question 14
list.content:
Consider the expansion of $(2x6+qx2​)10$, 
$q=0$. The coefficient of the term
in $x40$ is twelve times the coefficient of the term in $x36$.
Find $q$.
list.markScheme:
Using the binomial theorem, we have
$$$(2x6+qx2​)10​=k=0∑10​(k10​)[2x6]10−k[qx2​]k=k=0∑10​(k10​)[210−kq−k][x60−4k]​$$$
Hence we get
$$$[coefficient of the term in x40](510​)[210−5q−5]252[25q−5]​=12[coefficient of the term in x36]=12(610​)[210−6q−6]=12(210)[24q−6]​$$$
$$$q=5​[by using G.D.C.]$$$

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
In the expansion of $x(2x+1)n$, the coefficient of the term in $x3$
is $20n$, where $n∈Z+$. Find $n$.
list.markScheme:
Using the binomial theorem, we have
$$$20nx3​=x(2n​)[1n−2][(2x)2](1)​$$$
Hence, solving the equation $(1)$ for $n$, we get
$$$20nx320nx310n0​=x[2!(n−2)!n!​][4x2]=[2n(n−1)​][4x3]=n(n−1)=n(n−11)​$$$
$$$n=11​$$$

list.title: Question 16
list.content:
In the expansion of $(2x+1)n$, the coefficient of the term in $x2$
is $40n$, where $n∈Z+$. Find $n$.
list.markScheme:
Using the binomial theorem, we have
$$$40nx2​=(2n​)[1n−2][(2x)2](1)​$$$
Hence, solving the equation $(1)$ for $n$, we get
$$$40nx240n20n0​=[2!(n−2)!n!​][4x2]=[2n(n−1)​][4]=n(n−1)=n(n−21)​$$$
$$$n=21​$$$

list.title: Question 18
list.content:
Given that
$(5+nx)2(1+53​x)n=25+100x+⋯$,
find the value of $n$.
list.markScheme:
Using the binomial theorem, we have
$$$(5+nx)2(1+53​x)n​=[25+10nx+n2x2][k=0∑n​(kn​)[53x​]k](1)​$$$
The term in $x$ in the expansion of the product $(1)$ is
$$$25(1n​)[53x​]1+10nx(0n​)[53x​]0​=15nx+10nx=25nx​$$$
Hence we get
$$$25n​=100​$$$
$$$n=4​$$$

list.title: Question 19
list.content:
Consider the following equation $2(rn​)=(r+1n​)$.
Show that it can be written as $3r+2=n$.


Now consider the following equation $7(r−1n​)=2(rn​)$.
Show that it can be written as $9r−2=2n$.  [4]





Consider the expansion
$$$(1+x)n=1+a1​x+...+ak−1​xk−1+ak​xk+ak+1​xk+1+...+xn​$$$
Where $ai​∈Q$ and $k∈Z$.
The coefficients of three consecutive terms of the expansion are such that
$$$7×ak−1​​=2×ak​ and 14×ak​=7×ak+1​​$$$

Find $n$. [3]
list.markScheme:
Using the combinations formula $(rn​)=r!(n−r)!n!​$ we can rewrite both the LHS and the RHS of the equation
$$$2(r!(n−r)!n!​)​=(r+1)!(n−(r+1))!n!​​$$$
Now we can simplify and rearrange the equation
$$$r!2(r+1)!​​=(n−r−1)!(n−r)!​​$$$
Rewrite the numerators using the concept $n!=n(n−1)!$
$$$r!2(r+1)r!​​=(n−r−1)!(n−r)(n−r−1)!​​M1​$$$
We can cancel out the factorial terms
$$$r!2(r+1)r!​2(r+1)​=(n−r−1)!​(n−r)(n−r−1)!​​=n−r3r+2=n​​A1​$$$
As required.


Rewrite the equation using the combinations formula and simplify in a similar way to part (a)
$$$7((r−1)!(n−(r−1))!n!​)(r−1)!(n−r+1)!7​(r−1)!7r!​(r−1)!​7r(r−1)!​​7r​=2(r!(n−r)!n!​)=r!(n−r)!2​=(n−r)!2(n−r+1)!​=(n−r)!​2(n−r+1)(n−r)!​​=2n−2r+29r−2=2n​​M1A1​$$$
As required.




We can begin by expanding $(1+x)n$, using the binomial theorem, in terms of $n$ and $r$.
$$$(1+x)n​=1+(1n​)x+(2n​)x2+...+(r−1n​)xr−1+(rn​)xr+(r+1n​)xr+1+...+xn​(M1)​$$$
The terms in red represent any three consecutive terms in the expansion.
We are told in the question the way in which the coefficients of three consecutive terms are related.
$$$(1+x)n=1+a1​x+...+ak−1​xk−1+ak​xk+ak+1​xk+1+...+xn​$$$
Hence we can use the information given to write the following two equations in terms of binomial coefficients
$$$​​7×ak−1​7(r−1n​)​=2×ak​=2(rn​)​​​14×ak​14(rn​)2(rn​)​=7×ak+1​=7(r+1n​)=(r+1n​)​​$$$
In part (a) we already rewrote these equations without the combination notation, lets call them $[1]$ and $[2]$.
We can now solve them simultaneously and find $n$ and $r$.
$$$3r+29r−2​=n[1]=2n[2]​M1​$$$
Multiply $[1]$ by $3$ and subtract equation $[2]$ from this $result$
$$$9r−9r+6−(−2)​=3n−2nn=8​​A1​$$$

list.title: Question 20
list.content:
Given that $(1+x)3(1+px)4=1+qx+93x2+⋯+p4x7$, find
the possible values of $p$ and $q$.
list.markScheme:
Using Pascal triangle


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5ede89c3-3d7f-44a4-9286-c2554a148745/images/aebac82f-9280-4cf9-ad52-e4db6b3a6da0/d6143401ad9783a3554c63b7ab804d89d1d7b5f1.svg)


we have
$$$1+qx+93x2+⋯+p4x7​=(1+x)3(1+px)4=(1+3x+3x2+x3)(1+4px+6p2x2+4p3x3+p4x4)​$$$
Hence we get
$$$qxq​=4px+3x=4p+3(1)​$$$
and
$$$93x293​=6p2x2+12px2+3x2=6p2+12p+3(2)​$$$
Hence, solving the equation $(2)$ for $p$, we find
$$$6p2+12p+36p2+12p−90p2+2p−15(p+5)(p−3)p​=93=0=0=0=−5,3​$$$
Hence, substituting $p=−5,3$ in the
equation $(1)$, we obtain
$$$q​=4(−5)+3=−17​$$$
and
$$$q​=4(3)+3=15​$$$
Therefore
$p=−5,q=−17​$
and  $p=3,q=15​$
